definition: Illness enters by the mouth (idiom). Mind what you eat!/fig. A loose tongue may cause a lot of trouble.

from/through/via/to follow/to obey/to engage in (an activity)/never (in negative sentence)/(Taiwan pr. [zong4]) retainer/assistant/auxiliary/subordinate/related by common paternal grandfather or earlier ancestor
mouth/classifier for things with mouths (people, domestic animals, cannons, wells etc)/classifier for bites or mouthfuls
to enter/to go into/to join/to become a member of/to confirm or agree with/abbr. for 入聲|入声[ru4 sheng1]
Illness enters by the mouth, trouble comes out by the mouth (idiom). A loose tongue may cause a lot of trouble.
pinyin: bing4 cong2 kou3 ru4 , huo4 cong2 kou3 chu1

sentences.english: One must wash his hands before meals to avoid diseases.
sentences.chinese: 爲了避免病從口入，飯前要洗手。

sentences.english: According to ancient Chinese, "Illness enters through mouth".

definition: extreme joy turns to sorrow (idiom); Don't celebrate too soon, things could still go wrong!
Trouble issues from the mouth (idiom). A loose tongue may cause a lot of trouble.
it will cause no end of trouble (idiom)
lit. a horse that brings trouble to its herd (idiom)/fig. troublemaker/black sheep/rotten apple
lit. the disease is cured the moment the medicine is taken (idiom)/fig. (of a medical treatment) to give instant results/(of a solution or method) highly effective
lit. helping tyrant Zhou 商紂王|商纣王[Shang1 Zhou4 wang2] in his oppression (idiom)/fig. to take the side of the evildoer/giving succor to the enemy
